text: uh hey everyone there theny there tanto
here the Internet's busiest music nerd
and it is time for a review of the new
Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds album Ghost
teen this is the newest record from
legendary singer and songwriter Nick
Cave and his band the Bad Seeds who have
spent this decade sounding a lot more
mellow than bad with records like push
the sky away as well as skeleton tree
and now ghosting all three of these
albums essentially accounting for some
of the most ambient moody and low-key
records in the entire Nick Cave
discography and for me that's meant a
lot of highs and a lot of lows while I
wasn't crazy about push the sky away I
did love the profoundly dark and
mournful tone of skeleton tree and ghost
teen is essentially the third and final
installment in this very melancholic
trilogy now of course I can't say that I
was surprised to hear that ghost teen
was equally as low-key as its
predecessors especially since this album
comes well after the sudden passing of
Nick Cave son and Nick spends quite a
bit of time meditating on exactly that I
mean he is essentially the ghost teen
the album is titled after if anything is
surprising about this album though it is
the very lush and flowery cover
depicting this idyllic green garden with
flamingos and a horse and all these
flowers it's beautiful its inviting it
looks like something that would be on
the cover of a book of fables and Nick
uses exactly that iconography in his
lyrics to explore his grief whether he's
referencing kings and queens on the
opening spinning song or on this
collection of lyrics from the title
track the three bears watched the TV
they aged a lifetime oh Lord
mama bear holds the remote papa bear he
just floats and baby bear has gone to
the moon in a boat these are not
necessarily themes and aesthetics that I
typically muscles it with a Nick Cave
album that's not necessarily a bad thing
either I think a lot of the writing on
this thing is a welcome change of pace
for Nick but I do think there are some
elements of the music of the
instrumentation that doesn't fully line
up in fact ghost teen is like listening
to two albums within one album
and I don't just mean by virtue of this
thing being pretty much a double or a
two part album with a lot of these short
moody vignettes kicking off the first
portion and then we get these longer
monstrous ten minute plus cuts in the
second half no there's also the case of
the instrumental tone the instrumental
pallets of this project switching up and
not I guess cohesively flowing in a way
I care for that much it's either I'm
listening to Nick Cave totally broken up
over these ornately arranged beautiful
rich organic instrumentals with an
orchestral edge they're very weepy and
occasionally cinematic so we have that
where we're getting these long stretches
of time where Nick is crooning over
these minimal beds of synthesizers now
sometimes these Styles overlap and
pretty creatively I might add like on
the track galleon ship which transitions
from these droning very simple synth
leads to this gorgeous rush of strings
that is is really one of the prettiest
moments on the entire project but not
every synth bass track here meets that
same glorious finish nor is every synth
backed song on this record topped with
the same quality poetry I'm also left
wondering who exactly programmed these
synthesizers because the sounds they're
generating are not really all that great
or immersive or flavorful much of the
time the synths on this thing sound very
rudimentary clunky awkward tinny generic
I would say they ruin the moods of these
tracks more than they enhance them most
of the time and as long as we're talking
about the sound of ghost teen this
record is way too compressed for an
album that is this quiet the whole thing
just feels artificially loud and it's
especially distracting considering how
gentle the performances come off plus
there's at least a few tracks here
mostly ghost teen speaks as well as
Leviathan where I find the compositions
to be very banal and repetitive I get
that this record is mostly about just
kind of creating an instrumental vibe
for Nick to just do his thing vocally
and lyrically on top of again these
tracks are very much vignettes motifs
meditations extended quite a bit though
I like a good record you can really
marinate in the issue is I just don't
really want to marinate in the sounds of
the Nick and his band or generating here
I just don't find the generic synth
and occasionally sterile strains to be
all that intriguing now look this is not
the case for every track and if there is
a major saving grace to pretty much
every song here it is Nick's poetry it
is Nick's singing these characteristics
are really what make the sadness the
potent sadness of this record translate
so clearly especially on the opener
especially on the whimpering eerie
vocals and the second half of Hollywood
especially as on the track waiting for
you Nick's voice cracks like really hard
as he is singing waiting for you waiting
for you waiting for you making it easily
one of the most powerful vocal
performances of the year just from an
emotional standpoint also on this
project there are plenty of moments
where Nick's words reach poetic genius
like on the track Sun forest which
features all of this very surreal and
unsettling imagery of children climbing
up and up and up it's profoundly
chilling in one of the few moments on
this record where Nick's voice hits that
very grim Stern tone that he's known for
the title track which works in multiple
phases has this amazing build of strings
around the midpoint which is enhanced
with all these pianos and group
vocalists it's grand it's gorgeous it's
a high point on the album so there are
certainly things I appreciate about this
record and I think at the end of the day
I came out enjoying most of it I just
don't perceive it to be as one of Nick's
best though is it one of my favorite
sounding Nick Cave albums not really do
I think it's one of his best composed do
I think it's the most focused on the
concept at hand not necessarily but from
the standpoint of the vocals the lyrics
as well as some of the narratives coming
out of this thing it's easily one of
Nick caves best so if you're someone
who's more attracted to those elements
of music and songwriting I highly
recommend this record so it's certainly
likable I see why people are more into
it than I am and regardless of whether
or not this is one of my favorites of
Nick caves I am glad that he put out
this record and was bold enough to share
the turmoil he's been going through so
earnestly feeling a decent too strong
seven on this one transition have you
given this album a listen did you love
it did you hate it what would you rate
it you're the best you're the best what
should I review next hit the like if you
